awd_titl_txt: Development and Implementation of Workshops to Facilitate Capacity in Ocean Circulation, Ecosystem and Management Strategy Evaluation Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
U.S. scientists and students will participate in a series of three international training workshops focused on numerical modeling of the southern ocean. The three-year program is designed to train faculty and graduate students in the development and implementation of numerical models for ocean circulation, biogeochemistry and food webs and linking these models with socio-economic models through Management Strategy Evaluation (MSE) models. The first workshop will build upon the 2018 Austral Summer Institute (ASI) at Universidad de Concepcion, which has the theme, Numerical Modeling Tools to Understand Physical and Biological Processes in Mid and High Latitude Marine Ecosystems. Workshops in years 2 and 3 will focus on approaches and tools for numerical modeling of Antarctic systems and MSE models, respectively. International partners for the workshops include the Center of Excellence on the Dynamics of High Latitude Marine Ecosystems (IDEAL) at Universidad Austral de Chile in Valdivia, the Universidad de Concepcion, the Universidad de Magallanes in Punta Arenas, and Chinese faculty from Shanghai Jaio Tong University's Institute of Oceanography who collaborate with the IDEAL Center. These institutions will provide housing, conference facilities and computer resources necessary for the program.

The materials developed for the workshops (lectures, model codes, model implementations) will be available for the development of special lectures in university courses and archived on a dedicated website. The long-term plan is that the workshops will provide a framework for development of formal courses in numerical circulation and ecosystem modeling that will be included as part of the main curriculum in marine science programs in the U.S., Chile, South America, China and other international programs. Each workshop will consist of overview lectures that are followed with hands-on training. The expectation is that participants will continue to use and develop the models for their research projects after the workshop.

Intellectual Merit: The structure of the proposed workshops and the general plan for encouraging productive interactions between scientists and students is well developed. The workshops will focus on important scientific questions and development of related models will benefit greatly from the collaborative international environment.

Broader Impacts: Catalyzing connections between Antarctic scientists and development of an international scientific community with strong numerical modeling skills and a focus on the southern ocean will be an important outcome. US leadership in this international community will allow US faculty and students to expand their scientific connections and potential access to international collaborators.

por.por_cntn:
A lesson learned from the multidisciplinary oceanographic research programs that have been done in the past decades is that collaborations among scientists with expertise in measurements, data analysis, and numerical modeling are needed at every stage of a research program. Numerical modeling provides a focal point for developing these collaborations so that hypotheses, field programs, data analyses and syntheses provide a holistic approach for which limitations and uncertainties are addressed and quantified.  This project was designed to provide training in the development, implementation and linking of numerical models for ocean circulation, biogeochemistry and food webs.  Initially this training was to be provided through workshops that included hands-on training in numerical modeling techniques and implementation. Two international workshops were held at Universidad de Concepcion, Concepcion, Chile (January 2018) and Universidad de Austral, Valdivia, Chile (August 2019).  The intent was to continue these training workshops but Covid-19 restrictions on travel and in-person activities resulted in re-scoping of the project to focus on the development of online teaching materials for instruction in marine ecosystem modeling.

The online course on Quantitative Approaches to Marine Ecosystem Assessment that resulted from this project is structured around six modules that consider: 1) marine ecosystem modeling and the use of conceptual models as a basis for understanding these systems, 2) single species models, 3) basic predator-prey models, 4) advanced predator-prey models, 5) marine ecosystem models, and 6) Lagrangian models for marine ecosystems.  Each module includes assessments that learners can use to gain experience with the concepts presented in the module topics.  Ungraded learning checks challenge the learners with specific questions and/or problems that are based on specifics of models that are presented in a topic. Critical thinking questions challenge learners to understand the implications of concepts presented in the module topics.  The problem sets provide the opportunity to implement the modeling concepts covered in a module.

The online course is based on an open source version of Canvas.  The online course is undergoing testing as part of graduate course offerings at two universities.  Following the testing phase the course will be made available for marine ecosystem modeling instruction.
